#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER IX
#Text=Red-Eye was an atavism .
#Text=He was the great discordant element in our horde .
#Text=He was more primitive than any of us .
#Text=He did not belong with us , yet we were still so primitive ourselves that we were incapable of a cooperative effort strong enough to kill him or cast him out .
#Text=Rude as was our social organization , he was , nevertheless , too rude to live in it .
#Text=He tended always to destroy the horde by his unsocial acts .
#Text=He was really a reversion to an earlier type , and his place was with the Tree People rather than with us who were in the process of becoming men .
#Text=He was a monster of cruelty , which is saying a great deal in that day .
#Text=He beat his wives -- not that he ever had more than one wife at a time , but that he was married many times .
#Text=It was impossible for any woman to live with him , and yet they did live with him , out of compulsion .
#Text=There was no gainsaying him .
#Text=No man was strong enough to stand against him .
#Text=Often do I have visions of the quiet hour before the twilight .
#Text=From drinking-place and carrot patch and berry swamp the Folk are trooping into the open space before the caves .

#Text=They dare linger no later than this , for the dreadful darkness is approaching , in which the world is given over to the carnage of the hunting animals , while the fore-runners of man hide tremblingly in their holes .
#Text=There yet remain to us a few minutes before we climb to our caves .
#Text=We are tired from the play of the day , and the sounds we make are subdued .
#Text=Even the cubs , still greedy for fun and antics , play with restraint .
#Text=The wind from the sea has died down , and the shadows are lengthening with the last of the sun ’s descent .
#Text=And then , suddenly , from Red-Eye ’s cave , breaks a wild screaming and the sound of blows .
#Text=He is beating his wife .
#Text=At first an awed silence comes upon us .
#Text=But as the blows and screams continue we break out into an insane gibbering of helpless rage .
#Text=It is plain that the men resent Red-Eye ’s actions , but they are too afraid of him .
#Text=The blows cease , and a low groaning dies away , while we chatter among ourselves and the sad twilight creeps upon us .
#Text=We , to whom most happenings were jokes , never laughed during Red-Eye ’s wife-beatings .
#Text=We knew too well the tragedy of them .
#Text=On more than one morning , at the base of the cliff , did we find the body of his latest wife .
#Text=He had tossed her there , after she had died , from his cave-mouth .
#Text=He never buried his dead .
#Text=The task of carrying away the bodies , that else would have polluted our abiding-place , he left to the horde .
#Text=We usually flung them into the river below the last drinking-place .
#Text=Not alone did Red-Eye murder his wives , but he also murdered for his wives , in order to get them .
#Text=When he wanted a new wife and selected the wife of another man , he promptly killed that man .
#Text=Two of these murders I saw myself .
#Text=The whole horde knew , but could do nothing .
#Text=We had not yet developed any government , to speak of , inside the horde .
#Text=We had certain customs and visited our wrath upon the unlucky ones who violated those customs .

#Text=Thus , for example , the individual who defiled a drinking-place would be attacked by every onlooker , while one who deliberately gave a false alarm was the recipient of much rough usage at our hands .
#Text=But Red-Eye walked rough-shod over all our customs , and we so feared him that we were incapable of the collective action necessary to punish him .
#Text=It was during the sixth winter in our cave that Lop-Ear and I discovered that we were really growing up .
#Text=From the first it had been a squeeze to get in through the entrance-crevice .
#Text=This had had its advantages , however .
#Text=It had prevented the larger Folk from taking our cave away from us .
#Text=And it was a most desirable cave , the highest on the bluff , the safest , and in winter the smallest and warmest .
#Text=To show the stage of the mental development of the Folk , I may state that it would have been a simple thing for some of them to have driven us out and enlarged the crevice-opening .
#Text=But they never thought of it .
#Text=Lop-Ear and I did not think of it either until our increasing size compelled us to make an enlargement .
#Text=This occurred when summer was well along and we were fat with better forage .
#Text=We worked at the crevice in spells , when the fancy struck us .
#Text=At first we dug the crumbling rocks away with our fingers , until our nails got sore , when I accidentally stumbled upon the idea of using a piece of wood on the rock .
#Text=This worked well .
#Text=Also it worked woe .
#Text=One morning early , we had scratched out of the wall quite a heap of fragments .
#Text=I gave the heap a shove over the lip of the entrance .
#Text=The next moment there came up from below a howl of rage .
#Text=There was no need to look .
#Text=We knew the voice only too well .
#Text=The rubbish had descended upon Red-Eye .
